revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Rapha | logo = Rapha logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | caption = | type = | traded_as = Rapha Performance Roadwear | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 2004 | founder = [[Simon Mottram]] and [[Luke Scheybeler]] | location_city = [[London]] | location_country = [[England]] | location = | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Sporting goods]] | products = [[Clothing]]
[[Fashion accessory|Accessories]]
[[Skin care#Skin care products|Skin Care]]
[[Adventure travel|Cycling Holidays]]
[[Coffeehouse|Cafe]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.rapha.cc/ rapha.cc] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Rapha Performance Roadwear''' is a [[Sportswear (activewear)|sportswear]] and lifestyle brand focused on [[road bicycle racing]], clothing and accessories. Rapha headquarters are in [[London]] with a United States office in [[Portland, Oregon]].{{cite web|title=The Company|url=http://pages.rapha.cc/service/about-rapha/the-company|publisher=Rapha|accessdate=8 April 2014}} ==History== The company was started in [[London]] in early 2004 by [[Simon Mottram]]{{cite web|last=Penn|first=Rob|title=Pedalling fashion: the rise of cycle style|url=https://www.designweek.co.uk/issues/hot-50-supplement/hot-50-rapha/|publisher=Design Week}} and [[Luke Scheybeler]];{{cite web|last=Green|first=Lucie|title=New sportswear line|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a6984224-546b-11e4-b2ea-00144feab7de|publisher=Financial Times}} the first products were launched in July of that year. The name Rapha was taken from the 1960s cycling team [[Rapha (cycling team)|Rapha]], which was named after the [[Apéritif and digestif|apéritif]] drink company Saint Raphaël.{{cite web|title=The Original Rapha|url=http://inrng.com/2012/05/original-rapha-history/|work=The Inner Ring|accessdate=21 May 2013|date=16 May 2012}} In 2007, Rapha partnered with British designer [[Paul Smith (fashion designer)|Paul Smith]] to create a range of limited-edition cycle clothing and accessories.{{cite web|title=Rapha + Paul Smith collection unveiled|url=http://roadcyclinguk.com/news/gear-news/rapha-paul-smith-collection-unveiled.html|work=Road Cycling UK|accessdate=1 October 2012|date=28 July 2010}} In 2016, Rapha collaborated with bikepacking design pioneer Apidura on a limited range of cycling luggage{{Cite news|url=https://cyclingindustry.news/rapha-partners-apidura-for-bar-and-saddlebag-line/|title=Rapha partners Apidura for bar and saddlebag line|date=2016-06-15|work=Cycling Industry News|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en-GB}}. Rapha clothing is produced in a number of different locations including the UK, Italy and the Far East. UK production included some early Merino wool pieces and also leather gloves which are made in Somerset, England. Italian production focuses on stretch fabric and stretch garments such as shorts and tights. In China production focuses on the most technical items, such as outerwear. In recent years, Rapha has developed an international cycling club, in which members have access to exclusive club apparel and high-end bike rentals (currently supplied by [[Canyon Bicycles]]). The Rapha Cycling Club (RCC) hosts rides and events at stores known as Clubhouses in 21 international locations throughout the United States, Europe, Asia and Australia. Each clubhouse consists of a retail space that sells Rapha apparel and accessories, as well as a cafe that serves coffee and food while screening live cycle racing. Clubhouses also play host to a number of cycling-related events and art exhibitions throughout the year.http://pages.rapha.cc/clubs In August 2017, it was announced that Rapha would be purchased by RZC Investments, a company setup by [[Steuart Walton]], for £200m.{{cite web|title=Walmart heirs' fund wins £200m race for cycling brand Rapha|url=http://news.sky.com/story/walmart-heirs-fund-wins-200m-race-for-cycling-brand-rapha-10978288|accessdate=7 August 2017|date=7 August 2017}} ==Sponsorships== Rapha used to co-own the UK-based cycling team {{ct|RCS|2014}} with London bike brand [[Condor Cycles]] and the [[cyclocross]] team Rapha Focus; at the end of 2014 Rapha announced they would end their grassroots sponsorship to focus on Team Sky and {{ct|WGN}}.{{cite web |url=http://rapha-focus.cx/sponsors/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427233133/http://rapha-focus.cx/sponsors/ |archivedate=2014-04-27 |df= }} In August 2012, it was announced that as of 2013, Rapha would be producing the clothing for the British cycling team, {{ct|SKY|2013}}.{{cite web|last=Merrill|first=Jamie|title=Sky's the limit for cult clothing brand Rapha|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/skys-the-limit-for-cult-clothing-brand-rapha-8101496.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=1 October 2012|date=3 September 2012}} Australian Cyclocross champion for 2013 and 2014, Lisa Jacobs, chooses to wear Rapha clothing. On November 3, 2015, Rapha announced that their {{ct|SKY|2016}} sponsorship would end after the 2016 season. In an effort to grow and promote women's cycling, Rapha began supplying clothing to the [[UCI Women's WorldTour]] team [[Canyon-SRAM]].http://pages.rapha.cc/feature/canyon-sram-2016 ==See also== {{Portal|Sports|Fashion}} *[[Sportswear (activewear)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website}} [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:2004 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies based in the London Borough of Islington]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Sports clothing]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 2004]] {{clothing-stub}} {{cycling-stub}}

The '''Red Bull X-Alps''' is a [[paragliding]] race in which athletes must hike or fly 1,000 km across the Alps. It first launched in 2003 and has since taken place every other year. Around 30 athletes take part and must navigate their way via a predetermined set of turnpoints that vary with each race. Every kilometer must be covered either on [[foot]] or by paraglider. Teams consist of one athlete and one official supporter, whose role it is to provide technical advice, mental and nutritional support. The route traditionally covers the Alpine regions of [[Austria]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Switzerland]] and [[France]] before ending in Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, [[France]]. Athletes don't fly into Monaco due to airspace restrictions, and the term "Monaco" is used solely for marketing purposes. The exact route is normally unveiled in the spring before the race start. For the first time in the race's history, the 2017 route will feature [[Slovenia]]. New to the 2015 race was the Powertraveller Prologue, a one-day hike and paragliding contest in the Salzburgerland region. Starting and finishing in Fuschl am See, athletes had to hike or fly a 38 km course around two turnpoints, the Zwölferhorn and Schafberg peaks. It was won by Paul Guschlbauer in 2h 21m. In 2017, the prologue will return to Fuschl am See as the Leatherman Prologue on June 29. The 2015 race started July 5 and ended July 17. It was won for the fourth time in a row by the Swiss athlete Christian Maurer who reached the finish, a landing float in Monaco bay, on July 14. His official time, which stops at the final turnpoint of Peille above Monaco, was 8d 4h 37m. ==History== The concept for the Red Bull X-Alps was developed by Austrian pilot [[Hannes Arch]] who saw a TV documentary in which German pilot Toni Bender crossed the Alps from North to South by paraglider, carrying all his equipment, sleeping rough and hiking parts of the way. "I thought it would be cool to base a paragliding competition on this format and developed a basic concept for it - and the idea was born! Together with [[Red Bull]], we have developed it over the years to be the Red Bull X-Alps it is today - the toughest and most extreme endurance and outdoor race in the world. Its simplicity is what makes it most appealing. We start in Salzburg and whoever arrives in Monaco first wins. That's it. It's about body and soul, not about hundreds of rules and regulations," Arch has said.Red Bull X-Alps When conditions are good, athletes use [[paraglider]]s to fly, and when they are not they must run or hike, carrying their paraglider and other mandatory equipment. The use of [[tunnel]]s and all other form of transport is not permitted. The first edition led from Austria's [[Dachstein]] [[Glacier]] to Monaco via Germany's highest mountain, the [[Zugspitze]], [[Mont Blanc]] and Mont Gros in France. Seventeen athletes and their support teams covered a distance of 800 kilometers as the crow flies. Over the years the route and the turnpoints have changed. From 2009 the race started off in the Austrian city of [[Salzburg]]. At 1,031 kilometers, the 2013 course was the longest in the history of the race and athletes had to pass 10 turnpoints: [[Gaisberg]], Dachstein, and [[Wildkogel]] in Austria; Zugspitze in Germany; [[Ortler]]/[[Sulden]] in Italy; [[Interlaken]], [[Matterhorn]] in Switzerland; Mont Blanc, Saint Hilaire, and [[Peille]] in France. So far the race has only ever been won by Swiss nationals. Thanks to [[GPS]]-Live Tracking, all athletes can be followed in real time on the official website throughout the race. The exact position of the athletes is monitored via data loggers and GSM cell phones. The athletes also carry a camera with them at all times. Stills and videos are used in the athletes’ online diaries, which are kept up to date by their supporters. ==Rules== The first athlete to reach Monaco wins the race, which ends 48 hours later but not before a set finish time as defined by organizers. Thereafter, the race will officially end and athletes will be requested to stop racing. Pilots who have not reached the final destination within this time will be ranked according to the distance left to the final destination. Since the 2011 edition, athletes are forced to have a mandatory rest between 23:00 and 04:00 and stay within a radius of 250m of their resting position for safety reasons. In 2013, the mandatory break was extended by 1.5 hours, from 22:30 to 05:00. If an athlete was still moving in that time, he would be subjected to a minimum penalty of 24 hours. Athletes with penalty times had to prolong their next rest for the duration of their penalty time. Failure to comply with this rule led to disqualification. New in 2013 was the so-called Night Pass, which allowed athletes to hike through the night. To use they had to inform organizers of their intention by 12:00 local time the day they wished to use. The idea behind the Night Pass was to allow athletes a chance to advance their position by tactical means once during the race. They may be able to hike to a key point where they can extend their lead or pass teams in front. Since 2013, prototypes are banned from the competition and all equipment, including paragliders, harnesses and helmets must comply with EN or LTF certifications.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbullxalps.com/rules.html|title=Rules - Red Bull X-Alps|first= Red Bull|last=X-Alps|work=redbullxalps.com|accessdate=26 November 2016}} ==X-Alps 2003== ===Route=== The first course took the athletes from the Dachstein Glacier in Austria to Monaco. It was defined by two turnpoints, all of which had to be taken within a radius of 100 meters. Over the years the route and the turnpoints have changed. {| class="wikitable" |- ! # !! Müller was taken over by Alex Hofer and Toma Coconea at Mt Gros and only placed third. Winner Alex Hofer traveled 900 km (61% of the distance) in the air and walked 588 km (39%). In comparison, Coconea flew 24% of the distance and walked the other 76% (1,021 km). ==X-Alps 2009== ===Route=== For the first time the race started from the Mozartplatz in the center of the city of Salzburg, the end goal however remained the same. eliminated |} Defending champion Chrigel Maurer was the first to arrive in Monaco after 11 days, 4h and 52min after covering a total distance of 1,807 km, 1,321 km of which he covered by paraglider and 486 km on the ground. ==X-Alps 2013== ===Route=== Mozartplatz, Salzburg, Austria, to Monaco. {| class="wikitable" |- ! # !! Carlos Fernández Carrasco || || 877 km, eliminated |- |} At 1,031 km, the route was almost 200 km longer than in 2011. Chrigel Maurer was the first to arrive in Monaco, winning for the third time in a row. He made it in a record time of 6 days, 23h and 40min. He traveled a total distance of 2,556 km, 2,288 km of which he covered by paraglider and 268 km on the ground. ==X-Alps 2015== ===Route=== The route was announced on March 19, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.redbullxalps.com/race/route-2015.html |title= Red Bull X-Alps Route|first= Red Bull|last=X-Alps|work=redbullxalps.com|accessdate=26 November 2016}} It follows an arc of Europe's highest mountains, starting in Salzburg, Austria and finishing in Monaco. The 2015 route has ten turnpoints and a straight-line distance of 1,038 km and is more challenging tactically than the 2013 race due to it having less obvious flight paths. New to the 2015 edition was the Powertraveller Prologue, a one-day hike and paragliding race around the mountains of Fuschl am See. The first three athletes to finish the Prologue were each rewarded with a five-minute headstart in the Red Bull X-Alps race start on July 5 and an additional Led Lenser Nightpass to journey through the night, which is normally a mandatory rest period. First was Paul Guschlbauer (AUT1) 2h21m, second was Stanislav Mayer (CZE) in 2h22m, third was Gavin McClurg (USA2) 2h24m. {| class="wikitable" |- ! # !! Turnpoint !! |- | 1 || {{AUT|#}} || [[Gaisberg]] |- | 2 || {{AUT|#}} || [[Dachstein]] |- | 3 || {{GER|#}} || [[Aschau im Chiemgau|Aschau]] - [[Kampenwand|Chiemsee (Kampenwand)]] |- | 4 || {{AUT|#}} || [[Lermoos]] |- | 5 || {{ITA|#}} || [[Brenta group|Brenta]], [[Cima Tosa]] |- | 6 || {{SUI|#}} || [[St. Moritz]] - [[Corvatsch]] |- | 7 || {{SUI|#}} || [[Matterhorn]] |- | 8 || {{FRA|#}}/{{ITA|#}} || [[Mont Blanc]] |- | 9 || {{FRA|#}} || [[Annecy]] |- | 10 || {{FRA|#}} || [[Peille]] |} ===Teams and results=== On December 29, 2014 the first 31 teams were revealed. Two more wildcard teams were added to the starters field on January 8, 2015. first=Red Bull | last=X-Alps | work=redbullxalps.com | date=29 March 2017 | accessdate=29 March 2017}} With seven turnpoints and a straight-line distance of 1,138 km, it was the longest route so far. In 2017, the Prologue returned as the Leatherman Prologue race on June 29. The one-day hiking race which saw no paragliding due to bad weather took place around the mountains of Fuschl am See. The athletes started in Fuschl and reached the Zwölferhorn before returning to Fuschl as fast as possible. The first three athletes to finish the Prologue race were rewarded with a head start on day two of the main race and an additional Ledlenser Nightpass to journey through the night, which is normally a mandatory rest period.http://www.redbullxalps.com/race/prologue-2017.html {| class="wikitable" |- ! # !! revision.text:
[[Image:Camels with robot jockies.jpg|thumb|Camels mounted by robot jockeys]] A '''robot jockey''' is commonly used on [[camel]]s in [[camel racing]] as a replacement for human [[jockey]]s. Developed since 2004, the [[robot]]ic jockeys are slowly phasing out the use of human jockeys, which in the case of camel racing in [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Bahrain]], [[United Arab Emirates]], and [[Qatar]], often [[Child camel jockey|employs small children]] who reportedly suffer repeated systemic [[human rights abuse]]s. In response to international condemnation of such abuses, the nations of Qatar and the UAE have banned the use of human jockeys in favor of robots.
==Use of humans== [[File:Robotic camel jockey at Al Shahaniya Racetrack.jpg|thumb|Robot jockey at [[Al-Shahaniya]] Camel Racetrack]] Camel racing has been around for thousands of years. "The Sport of [[Sheikh|Sheiks]]" almost exclusively utilized small children, usually boys around the age of four, to ride and direct the camels. Often, the boys would be [[starvation|starved]] to be as light as possible. Many of the boys used for the races were often sold to race organizers or camel owners, and there was an active [[child slavery|child]] [[slave trade]] for camel jockeys, involving victims of kidnapping or the children of destitute families who sold them into servitude.<ref name=USAToday>[https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/robotics/2005-04-19-qatar-camalbots_x.htm "Qatar to use robots as camel riders"] by Tarek Al-Issawi of the [[Associated Press]] via [[USA Today]], 2005-04-19.</ref><ref name=Wired>[https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.11/camel.html?pg=1&topic=camel&topic_set= "Robots of Arabia"] by Jim Lewis, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', Issue 13.11, November 2005.</ref>
==Banning of child jockeys== The [[United Arab Emirates]] was the first to ban the use of children under 15 as jockeys in the popular local sport of camel racing when [[Sheikh]] [[Hamdan bin Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan|Hamdan bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] announced the ban on July 29, 2002.<ref>[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle.asp?xfile=data/theuae/2005/May/theuae_May691.xml&section=theuae UAE enforces stringent steps to eradicate child jockeys] (Wam), ''[[Khaleej Times]]'', 24 May 2005</ref> The UAE issues penalties such as jail and banning for those found using children as jockeys.
In [[Qatar]], the [[Emir of Qatar]], [[Sheikh Hamad Bin Khalifa Al-Thani]], banned child jockeys in 2005<ref name=GUK>[https://www.theguardian.com/life/thisweek/story/0,12977,1458529,00.html Can robots ride camels?] by Ian Sample, ''[[The Guardian]]'', Thursday, 2005-04-14</ref> and directed that, by 2007, all camel races would be directed by robotic jockeys.<ref name=Wired/>
==Development and usage== [[Image:Robot jockey army.jpg|thumb|Robot jockeys]]
The government of Qatar initiated development of the robots at the beginning of 2001. The first successful model was made in 2003 by Stanely in co-ordination with Rashid Ali Ibrahim from the Qatar Scientific Club. At the end of 2003, the design, with a revised analysis, was tendered to [[Switzerland|Swiss]] robotics firm K-Team. Initial problems faced by the design team, led by Alexandre Colot, included the fact that the camels were conditioned to the use of human jockeys. Early designs confused or frightened the camels.<ref name=Wired/> The designs were modified to include more human-like features, including a [[mannequin]]-like face, [[sunglasses]], hats, [[racing silks]] and even traditional perfumes used by human jockeys.<ref name=USAToday/> Other technical issues included the conditions that the robots and the computers would be put under: the high temperatures of a dusty desert environment along with a fast-moving and uneven ride. The first successful official race featuring robotic jockeys was conducted in Qatar by 2005. The robots are [[aluminum]]-framed with a "thorax" about the size of a large book and contain small hinged arms that control the whip and the reins. The robot can also monitor and transmit the speed and heart rate of the camel.
Due to their heavy weight (16 to 18 kg) and high cost, the Swiss product was ruled out and replaced by smaller, lighter (2 to 3 kg) and lower-priced models in Qatar and the UAE. The newer models were developed using RKE systems further enhanced with two-way radio controls and GSM mobile controls by HM Maruff and, later, a "Voice & Hit Command Robot with Shock Sensor" following further research at the RAQBI Centre.
The robots are remote controlled by operators being driven alongside the race track in [[sport utility vehicle|SUV]]s.<ref name=Wired/>
==Current usage== Widespread usage is initiated from [[Qatar]] and [[UAE]] and further extended to all [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf|GCC countries]] where the robots have been widely accepted.<ref name=AP2>[http://www.gosanangelo.com/news/2006/dec/07/camel-racing-sport-sheiks/ "Camel racing 'sport of sheiks'"] by Eric Talmadge of the [[Associated Press]] via ''The San Angelo Standard-Times'', 2006-12-07</ref>
==References== [http://www.raqbi.com RAQBI Centre] - Robotics Academy of Qatar for Bright Inventions [http://www.intltravelnews.com/2006/07/camel-racing-meets-technology/] Travel article about camel racing {{reflist}}

Fashion Model Management (Milan)
The Squad (London)
Dominique Models (Brussels)
Two Management (Copenhagen, Los Angeles)
SPIN Model Management (Hamburg) https://models.com/models/rose-bertram | children = 1 }} '''Stephanie Rose Bertram''', or '''Stephanie Bertram-Rose''', most commonly known as '''Rose Bertram''' (born 26 October 1994),{{cite web |url=http://www.public.fr/Dossiers/La-bombe-Public/Toutes-les-bombes-Public/Photos-La-bombe-Public-Rose-Bertram-la-Belge-qui-nous-fait-tout-sauf-rire-816927 |title=Photos: La Bombe Public: Rose Bertram, la Belge qui nous fait tout sauf rire! |website=Public |date=21 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904020342/http://www.public.fr/Dossiers/La-bombe-Public/Toutes-les-bombes-Public/Photos-La-bombe-Public-Rose-Bertram-la-Belge-qui-nous-fait-tout-sauf-rire-816927 |archivedate=4 September 2015 |language=French }}{{cite web |first=Pierre |last=Nizet |url=http://www.sudinfo.be/988200/article/2014-04-18/stephanie-la-belge-qui-sort-avec-une-star-du-psg-veut-devenir-un-ange-de-victori |title=Stephanie, la Belge qui sort avec une star du PSG, veut devenir un ange de Victoria's Secret |website=Sudinfo.be |date=18 April 2014 |language=French }} is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[model (person)|model]]. ==Early life and family== Rose was born in [[Kortrijk]]; her father is [[Belgian]] while her mother is [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]], [[Angola]]n, and [[Senegalese]] descent.{{cite web|title=Konuk Van Der Wiel'in Kız Arkadaşı Rose Bertram|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NTt3fWZgP1E|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=10 May 2017}} Her mother signed her with a modeling agency when she was 13. She was raised in [[Flanders]], the Dutch-speaking part of Belgium, in [[Deinze]].{{cite news |url=http://www.esquire.com/lifestyle/sex/a36048/women-we-love-of-instagram-rose-bertram/ |title=Women We Love of Instagram: Rose Bertram |newspaper=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |date=28 June 2015 }}{{cite web |url=https://intothegloss.com/2015/01/stephanie-bertram-rose/ |title=Rose Bertram, Model |website=Into the Gloss |date=January 2015 }} ==Career== Bertram was cast by the Dominique agency at 16{{cite news |first=Eugénie |last=Rittweger de Moor |url=http://www.elle.be/fr/60086-girl-stephanie-bertram-rose.html |title=Stephanie Bertram Rose la top belge qui monte |newspaper=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]] |location=Belgium |language=French |date=4 November 2014 }} and first attracted notice in a photo-shoot with [[Juergen Teller]] for [[Jambox]]; she has since appeared in campaigns for [[H&M]], [[L'Oréal]], [[Hunkemöller]], [[Primark]],{{cite web |author=Zoé |url=http://www.grazia.nl/showbizz/rose-bertram-tegen-victorias-secret-zeg-ik-geen-nee |title=Rose Bertram: 'Tegen Victoria's Secret zeg ik geen nee' |website=Grazia.nl |date=5 August 2015 |language=Dutch }} and [[Agent Provocateur (lingerie)|Agent Provocateur]] among others.{{cite news |url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Sportlife/Bellezze/16-08-2015/rose-bertram-lady-van-der-wiel-super-sexy-l-agent-provocateur-120961110638.shtml |title=Rose Bertram, lady Van der Wiel super sexy per Agent Provocateur |newspaper=[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]] |date=16 August 2015 |language=Italian }} She moved to the United States when she turned 18, and signed with Marilyn. She has been the subject of photo articles in ''[[Oyster (magazine)|Oyster]]'', shot by [[Tyler, the Creator]],{{cite news |url=http://www.oystermag.com/rose-bertram-shot-by-tyler-the-creator |title=Born In 94: Rose Bertram Shot by Tyler, The Creator |newspaper=[[Oyster (magazine)|Oyster]] |date=11 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220155043/http://www.oystermag.com/rose-bertram-shot-by-tyler-the-creator |archivedate=20 December 2015 |df= }} and in ''Galore'',{{cite news |url=https://galoremag.com/rose-bertram-elias-tahan-editorial-new-years-eve/ |title=Rose Bertram Shows Us 5 Ways To Look Perfect On New Years Eve |newspaper=Galore |date=31 December 2015 }} and modeled for several fashion houses.{{cite web |url=https://models.com/models/rose-bertram |title=Rose Bertram |website=Models.com |accessdate=2 October 2016 }} In 2015 she became the first Belgian model to be featured in promotion for the ''[[Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue]]''. == Personal life == Bertram lives with the Dutch football player [[Gregory van der Wiel]],{{cite web |first=Alice |last=Casely-Hayford |url=http://www.hungertv.com/feature/meet-the-model-rose-bertram/ |title=Meet the Model: Rose Bertram |website=Hunger TV |date=4 February 2015 }} whom she met when she was 17.{{cite news |first=Lauren |last=Bastide |url=http://www.sportetstyle.fr/article/people/a,2569,gregory-van-der-wiel-et-rose-bertram-power-couple.html |title=Gregory van der Wiel et Rose Bertram: power couple |newspaper=[[L'Équipe|Sport&Style]] |date=3 February 2016 |language=French }} They previously lived in Paris; after his transfer to the Turkish club [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] in 2016, they moved to [[Istanbul]].{{cite web |url=http://www.medyafaresi.com/haber/fenerbahceli-wan-der-wielin-esi-istanbulda-bir-idol-haline-geldi/789070 |title=Fenerbahçeli Wan der Wiel'in eşi Rose Bertram İstanbul'da bir idol haline geldi! |website=Medyafaresi |date=31 August 2016 |language=Turkish }} It was announced that Rose and Gregory welcomed a daughter named Naleya Rose van der Wiel on 24 February 2018 in Toronto.{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/laparisienne/actualites/people/rose-bertram-et-gregory-van-der-wiel-sont-parents-d-une-petite-fille-27-02-2018-7581876.php|title=Rose Bertram et Gregory van der Wiel sont parents d’une petite fille|publisher=Le Parisien|language=French|date=27 February 2018|accessdate=10 March 2018}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{Facebook|ste.bertram}} {{2010–2019 Sports Illustrated Swimsuit}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bertram, Rose}} [[Category:1994 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kortrijk]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Belgian female models]] [[Category:Belgian people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Belgian people of Portuguese descent]] [[Category:Belgian people of Senegalese descent]] [[Category:IMG Models models]]

[[Major Dhyan Chand Sports College, Saifai]] | international = true | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | firstodidate = | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | firstt20idate = | firstt20iyear = | firstt20ihome = | firstt20iaway = | lastt20idate = | lastt20iyear = | lastt20ihome = | lastt20iaway = | year1 = 2018 – present | club1 = [[Uttar Pradesh Cricket Association|UPCA]] | year2 = | club2 = | date = | year = | source = }} '''Saifai International Cricket Stadium''' is a cricket stadium of International Standard in [[Saifai]] ([[Etawah district]]), [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]].{{cite web|url=http://shasanadesh.up.nic.in/GO/ViewGOPDF_list_user.aspx?id1=NTkjMjA4IzEjMjAxNQ==|title=ǒवषय :- सैफई जनपद इटावा मɅ अÛ तरा[ç Ěȣय è तर के ǑĐके ट è टेǑडयम के िनमा[ण से सà बǔÛधत Ĥारǔàभक Ĥायोजना Ĥè ताव/आगणन कȧ è वीकृ ित के सà बÛ ध मɅ।|website=Shasanadesh.up.nic.in|accessdate=29 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/sport/other-sports/in-the-middle-of-nowhere-saifai-attempts-to-emerge-as-a-major-sporting-hub/article8557309.ece|title=In the middle of nowhere, Saifai attempts to emerge as a major sporting hub|first=Uthra|last=Ganesan|date=5 May 2016|accessdate=29 October 2017|website=Thehindu.com}}{{cite web|url=https://m.livehindustan.com/uttar-pradesh/mainpuri/story-yogi-sarkar-happy-at-the-saifai-international-cricket-stadium-1765590.html|title=सैफई अंतर्राष्ट्रीय क्रिकेट स्टेडियम पर मेहरबान हुई योगी सरकार|website=livehindustan.com}} It is situated in [[Major Dhyan Chand Sports College, Saifai|Major Dhyan Chand Sports College]] campus. With a seating capacity of 43,000 people, it is one of the largest cricket stadium in India (capacity wise). There is an All-weather Swimming Pool, Athletics Stadium and Indoor Stadium too in the campus of Sports College([[Major Dhyan Chand Sports College, Saifai]]) along with this cricket stadium. First tournament it hosted was Indian Gramin Cricket League (IGCL) in 2017.{{cite web|url=https://m.jagran.com/uttar-pradesh/etawah-igcl-winner-by-making-lucknow-dsd-17427495.html|title=लखनऊ डीएसडी बना आइजीसीएल का विजेता|publisher=}} It was inaugurated by [[Yogi Adityanath]] during his first official visit of [[Etawah]] as Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh on 1Jun 2018, along with [[Etawah Safari Park]] and Abhinav Vidyalaya, Saifai at a function in [[Etawah|Etawah city]].https://m.jagran.com/uttar-pradesh/etawah-civic-18028257.html ==See also== *[[Green Park Stadium]] *[[Ekana International Cricket Stadium]] *[[Major Dhyan Chand Sports College, Saifai]] *[[Master Chandgiram Sports Stadium]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in Uttar Pradesh]] [[Category:Sports venues in Uttar Pradesh]] [[Category:Saifai]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2018]] [[Category:2018 establishments in India]] {{India-sports-venue-stub}}

The '''Tennessee State Fairground Sports Arena''' is an arena in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], on the grounds of the [[Tennessee State Fair]]. It is also known by the nickname the '''TNA Asylum''' due to the venue hosting Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA, now [[Impact Wrestling]]) events for two years in the early 2000s.
==History== The building was constructed in 1922, by workers from [[South Dakota]]. The building was originally a flea market. It was operated throughout the 1960s and 1970s by promoter [[Nick Gulas]] as a [[professional wrestling]] venue.
After taping their initial shows in the [[Von Braun Center]] in [[Huntsville, Alabama]], then moving their next few to the [[Nashville Municipal Auditorium]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], TNA moved their weekly pay-per-view events to the Tennessee State Fairgrounds Sports Arena in July 2002. The name "TNA Asylum" was first used during the ninth weekly pay-per-view by [[Ron Killings]]. The Asylum also served as the home of ''[[TNA Xplosion]]'', TNA's weekly syndicated television show, from its inception until October 2004.
After debuting ''[[TNA Impact!]]'', which was taped at [[Impact Wrestling Zone|Soundstage 21]] at [[Universal Studios Florida]], TNA decided that they would eventually shut down their weekly pay-per-view operations in favor of switching to a monthly pay-per-view format. Shortly after, they held their final weekly pay-per-view event (on September 8, 2004) before permanently departing from the Asylum in favor of running their shows exclusively out of Universal Soundstage 21.
[[Showtime All-Star Wrestling]] used the arena a couple times during the year of 2009, filming some of their television episodes at the Sports Arena.
On October 6, 2009 it was announced that the Nashville Mayor [[Karl Dean]] would be closing down the Tennessee State Fairgrounds at the end of June 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nashvillecitypaper.com/content/city-news/mayors-statement-puts-end-state-fair|title=Mayor's statement puts an end to State Fair|publisher=[[The City Paper]]|date=2009-10-06|accessdate=2009-10-07}}</ref>
On November 12, 2010, TNA Wrestling returned to the Asylum for a one last [[House show|live event]], headlined by [[Jeff Hardy]] defending the [[TNA World Heavyweight Championship]] against [[Elijah Burke|D'Angelo Dinero]], before the proposed demolition of the building.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/18323/|title=TNA house show report 11-12 Nashville|last=Goodman|first=Larry|date=2010-11-13|accessdate=2010-11-13|work=[[Dave Meltzer#Wrestling Observer Newsletter|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]}}</ref> However, on January 18, 2011, the Nashville City Council voted to keep the arena open through 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/news/171378/Former-TNA-Asylum-to-Be-Kept-Open.htm|title=Former TNA Asylum to Be Kept Open|last=Thomas|first=Jeremy|date=2011-01-23|accessdate=2011-01-24|work=411Mania}}</ref> The vote on a [[referendum]] issue on the ballot for the August 2011 [[Davidson County, Tennessee|Metro Nashville-Davidson County]] election made it much harder legally for the municipality either to dispose of or severely alter the operation of the Fairgrounds, and most of the facilities there remain in at least limited operation as of 2015.
On January 29, 2011, there was a "Tribute to the Fairgrounds" pro wrestling event, highlighting many of the Memphis-area wrestling legends who helped make the arena famous, with the main event being [[Jerry Lawler|Jerry "The King" Lawler]] vs [[Bill Dundee|"Superstar" Bill Dundee]] in front of a sold-out crowd of 1,700.
Beginning in 2012, Crossfire Entertainment used the Sports Arena for their live events. They hosted "Tribute to the Fairgrounds" events before the proposed demolition, but later used it as a primary location for their shows. On August 4, 2012, Crossfire Wrestling announced TV production would return to the Nashville Fairgrounds Sports Arena, thanks to [[Paramount Pictures]], as they were to be hosting HD/3D TV Tapings there. To add on to this, Crossfire was to be the first professional wrestling organization to be shot in [[3D television|3D]]. On February 17, 2013, Crossfire Wrestling announced that they had to cease operations, leaving the venue empty for the time being.<ref>[http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=75491]</ref>
On September 6, 2013, TCW Wrestling's "Tennessee Takeover" was held at the Sports Arena, which was the first event held in the arena since January 2013. On June 22, 2014, the first-ever live televised pay-per-view for [[Ring of Honor]], [[Best in the World 2014]], was held at the venue.
On October 21, 2018, the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] held its 70th Anniversary show in the building, garnering the biggest gate revenue for a professional wrestling show in the venue's history.
[[Impact Wrestling]] is set to return to The Asylum on January 6, 2019 with a PPV event called [[Impact Wrestling Homecoming|Homecoming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fightful.com/wrestling/impact-wrestling-announces-homecoming-ppv-january-6th-nashville-tennessee|title=IMPACT Wrestling Announces 'Homecoming' PPV For January 6th In Nashville, Tennessee - Fightful Wrestling|work=www.fightful.com|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref>

The film has stars like [[Reginald Denny (actor)|Reginald Denny]], [[Mabel Julienne Scott]] and [[Charles K. French]].Munden p.2 It is an adaptation of the 1911 novel ''[[The Abysmal Brute]]'' by [[Jack London]]. == Story: == A [[boxer]] raised in the mountains by his father comes to [[San Francisco]] and enjoys great success, but his lack of social skills means he struggles to romance the [[socialite]] he has fallen in love with. ==Cast== * [[ Reginald Denny (actor)| Reginald Denny]] as Pat Glendon, Jr * [[Mabel Julienne Scott]] as Maude Sangster * [[Charles K. French]] as Pat Glendon, Sr * [[Hayden Stevenson]] as Sam Stubener * [[David Torrence]] as Mortimer Sangster * George Stewart as Wilfred Sangster * Buddy Messinger as Buddy Sangster * [[Crauford Kent ]] as Deane Warner * [[Dorothea Wolbert]] as Mrs. MacTavish * Julia Brown as Violet MacTavish * Harry Mann as Abe Levinsky * Kid Wagner as Battling Levinsky * Jack Herrick as Rough House Ratigan * Irene Haisman as Gwendolyn * Nell Craig as Daisy Emerson * [[Will Walling]] as Farrell ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Munden, Kenneth White. ''The American Film Institute Catalog of Motion Pictures Produced in the United States, Part 1''. University of California Press, 1997. ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0013814}} [[Category:1923 films]] [[Category:1920s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:Films directed by Hobart Henley]] [[Category:American silent feature films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] {{silent-film-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abysmal Brute}}

{{Distinguish|Heckler (film)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Heckler | image = | image size = | caption = | director = [[Del Lord]] | producer = [[Charley Chase]]
Del Lord
Hugh McCollum | writer = John Grey | narrator = | starring = [[Charley Chase]]
[[Bruce Bennett]]
[[Richard Fiske]] | cinematography = [[Henry Freulich]] | editing = Arthur Seid | distributor = | released = 1940 | runtime = 20 mins | country = United States | language = English }} '''''The Heckler''''' (1940) is an American short film produced by [[Columbia Pictures Corporation]] directed by [[Del Lord]] and starring [[Charley Chase]]. ==Plot== At a baseball game, an irritating heckler ([[Charley Chase]]) annoys the crowd and the players with his obnoxious taunts. ==Reception== ''The Heckler'' has received positive reviews. [[Hal Erickson (author)|Hal Erickson]] wrote that, "The Heckler is without question one of the most consistently funny shorts ever assembled at Columbia, not to mention one of Charley Chase's most hilarious performances."{{cite book|last=Erickson|first=Hal|title=The baseball filmography, 1915 through 2001|year=2002|publisher=McFarland|isbn=0786412720|page=494|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HuBkAAAAMAAJ}} In his book ''The Great Baseball Films,'' Rob Edelman described ''The Heckler'' as "one of the best-ever baseball-related talkie shorts."{{cite book|last=Edelman|first=Rob|title=The Great Baseball Films|year=1994|publisher=Carol Pub. Group|page=104|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MPwHAQAAMAAJ}} Film critic [[Leonard Maltin]] wrote that ''The Heckler'' was one of Charley Chase's "best starring comedies"{{cite book|last=Maltin|first=Leonard|title=Leonard Maltin's movie encyclopedia|year=1994|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BKEYAQAAIAAJ}} and included it in his book "The Great Movie Shorts."{{cite book|last=Maltin|first=Leonard|title=The Great Movie Shorts|year=1972|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w22GAAAAIAAJ}} It was remade with minimal stock footage as "Mr.Noisy" starring Shemp Howard in 1946.{{Cite web|url=http://threestooges.net/filmography/episode/280|title=ThreeStooges.net :: MR. NOISY|last=Davidson|first=Robert|website=threestooges.net|access-date=2016-08-04}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|tt0031410}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Heckler, The}} [[Category:1940 films]] [[Category:1940s comedy films]] [[Category:1940s short films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Films directed by Del Lord]] {{short-comedy-film-stub}} [[Category:Comedy short films]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Tony’s Pizza Events Center | nickname = ''Bi Center'', ''Mid-America's Meeting Place'' | logo_image = Tony’s Pizza Events Center logo.png | image = | caption = | location = 800 The Midway
[[Salina, Kansas]] 67401 | coordinates = {{coord|38.833824|-97.600265|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1977{{cite news|last1=Curran|first1=Julie|title=Motels grow to meet expected demand created by BiCenter |url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/17843160/|accessdate=February 26, 2017|work=The Salina Journal|date=January 25, 1979|location=Salina, Kansas |pages=25 |language=en}} | opened = June 2, 1979{{cite news|last1=Demuth|first1=Gary|title=As Salina ages, the Bicentennial Center gets a facelift |url=http://www.salina.com/special_editions/progress_2/as-salina-ages-the-bicentennial-center-gets-a-facelift/article_f476429d-ad9a-5f4f-940c-1bc492400eb6.html |accessdate=February 26, 2017|work=Salina Journal|date=February 22, 2015|language=en}} | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Salina, Kansas|City of Salina]] | operator = [[Comcast Spectacor|Global Spectrum]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | general_contractor = | seating_capacity = 7,583{{cite web|title=SALINA DOWNTOWN REVITALIZATION: STAR BOND PROJECT PLAN|url=http://www.salina-ks.gov/filestorage/18394/18516/26070/3_-_STAR_Bond_Project_Plan.pdf|website=salina-ks.gov|publisher=City of Salina|accessdate=February 26, 2017|page=125|date=June 21, 2016}} | former_names = Salina Bicentennial Center (1979–2017) | tenants = [[Kansas Cagerz]] ([[USBL]]) (1999–2007)
[[Salina Rattlers]] ([[International Basketball Association|IBA]]) (2000–2001)
[[Salina Bombers]] ([[Champions Professional Indoor Football League|CPIFL]]/[[Champions Indoor Football|CIF]]) (2013–2015)
[[Salina Liberty]] (CIF) (2016–present)
[[Salina Saints]] ([[American Basketball Association (2000-present)|ABA]]) (2016–present) }} '''Tony’s Pizza Events Center''', formerly the '''Bicentennial Center''', is located in [[Salina, Kansas]]. It includes a 7,583-seat multipurpose [[arena]], meeting rooms and Heritage Hall, an 18,000 square foot [[convention center]]. It is home of the [[Salina Liberty]] of the [[Champions Indoor Football]] league, and is nicknamed ''Mid-America's Meeting Place''. On February 22, 2017, it was announced that the name of the Bicentennial Center would be changed to the Tony's Pizza Events Center, effective immediately.{{cite web|last1=Montague|first1=Sharon|title=BiCenter to be called Tony's Pizza Events Center|url=http://www.salina.com/news/local/bicenter-to-be-called-tony-s-pizza-event-center/article_e0f189a6-de16-5ef3-9ddd-ed3160997abd.html|website=Salina Journal|accessdate=February 25, 2017|language=en|date=February 22, 2017}} The City of Salina is the primary owner of the center. [[Comcast Spectacor#Spectra|Spectra]] manages the center as well as more than 100 other public assembly facilities around the world. A variety of events are held at the events center, including concerts, family shows, sport events, trade shows, and conventions. Annual events include: Salina Invitational Basketball Tournament, Salina Home & Leisure Show, [[Kansas State High School Activities Association]] (KSHSAA) 4A Wrestling, Basketball and Volleyball State Tournaments, [[National Junior College Athletic Association]] (NJCAA) Women's Division I Basketball National Championship, Mid-America Farm Expo, Shrine Circus, Tri-Rivers Fair, and commencements for [[Salina Area Technical College]], [[Brown Mackie College]], and USD 305. The arena has been home to five professional sports franchises: the [[Kansas Cagerz]] of the [[USBL|United States Basketball League]] (1999–2007), the [[Salina Rattlers]] of the [[International Basketball Association]] (2000–2001), the [[Salina Bombers]] of the [[Champions Indoor Football]] league (2013–2015), the [[Salina Liberty]], also of the CIF (2016–present), and the [[Salina Saints]] of the [[American Basketball Association (2000-present)|American Basketball Association]] (2016–present). ==History== The first concert at the center was the Osmonds, on June 2, 1979. The concert sold out, and there was a crowd of 7,300.{{cite news|first1=Nate|last1=Jenkins|title=20 YEARS OF SALINA BICENTENNIAL CENTER: Concerts have made center popular|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/2267884/|accessdate=February 26, 2017|work=Newspapers.com|date=September 19, 1999|location=Salina, Kansas|page=5|language=en}} On August 26, 1990, the rock band [[Kiss (band)|KISS]] performed at the arena as part of their [[Hot in the Shade Tour]]. During the show, the band's enormous stage set overloaded the arena's power supply causing a transformer to explode outside the building and cutting electricity inside the arena. This abruptly ended the show before the band could complete their set. A short time later, band member [[Paul Stanley]] phoned a local radio station and promised to return to Salina to make up for the shortened show. This phone call was recorded and played on the air. To date, KISS has never returned. On February 22, 2017, the center was renamed from Salina Bicentennial Center to Tony's Pizza Event Center, described as "the largest [[pizza]] facility in the world.” A food service subsidiary of [[Schwan Food Company]] paid $1,200,000 to receive comprehensive naming rights for 15 years. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.tonyspizzaeventscenter.com/ Official website] {{CIF Arenas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tony's Pizza Events Center}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Kansas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Salina, Kansas]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Kansas]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Kansas]] [[Category:1979 establishments in Kansas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1979]]

{{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Women's football in Argentina | image = | imagesize = 240px | image_alt = | caption = | union = [[Argentina Football Association]] | country = Argentina | sport = football | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = [[Argentina women's national football team|Women's national team]] | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = | club_list = [[Campeonato de Fútbol Feminino]] | intl_list = [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]]
[[FIFA Women's World Cup]](National Team)
[[Copa América Femenina]](National Team) | match = | league = }} '''Women's football in Argentina''' has struggled to find a mainstream audience.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/argentine-women-fight-against-inequality-in-soccer/2018/11/07/62a57ec4-e2a1-11e8-ba30-a7ded04d8fac_story.html|title=Argentine women fight against inequality in soccer|date=|accessdate=|website=Washington Post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wbur.org/onlyagame/2013/01/26/women-soccer-argentina|title=Argentine Women Seek Equality On The Pitch|website=www.wbur.org|accessdate=12 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/f5808116c84e477791d105265f48208a|title=Argentine women fight against inequality in soccer|date=7 November 2018|publisher=|accessdate=12 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.teenvogue.com/story/argentine-girls-soccer-team-la-nuestra|title=How This Girls’ Soccer Team Is Fighting Sexism|first=Anna-Catherine|last=Brigida|publisher=|accessdate=12 November 2018}}{{cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09523360500035867|title=The Place of Women in Argentinian Football|first=María Graciela|last=Rodríguez|date=1 March 2005|publisher=|journal=The International Journal of the History of Sport|volume=22|issue=2|pages=231–245|accessdate=12 November 2018|doi=10.1080/09523360500035867}}{{cite web|url=http://www.batimes.com.ar/news/sports/womens-football-in-argentina-a-struggle-between-inequality-and-indifference.phtml|title=Women’s football in Argentina: a struggle between inequality and indifference|date=12 November 2018|publisher=|accessdate=12 November 2018}} While women's football clubs have existed in Argentina for decades, especially in the rural, in 1991 that a grooup of clubs were allowed into the AFA (Argentina Football Association). Originality with seven teams, the country saw the number of clubs with female teams rising 35 in 1998, and then steadily plummet due to lack of interest.{{cite news|title= Somethin’ for the Ladies: Female Football in Argentina|publisher= The Argentina Independent|date=|url= http://www.argentinaindependent.com/life-style/sport/somethin-for-the-ladies-female-football-in-argentina/|accessdate=2012-07-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/96148/women%E2%80%99s-soccer-in-argentina |title=Women’s soccer in Argentina |publisher=BuenosAiresHerald.com |date=2012-03-23 |accessdate=2012-10-01}} Many women face prejudice and stigma for playing the game. {{cite web|url=http://onlyagame.legacy.wbur.org/2013/01/26/women-soccer-argentina|title=Argentine Women Seek Equality On The Pitch|date=26 January 2013|website=Onlygame.legacy.wbur.org|accessdate=4 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2015/07/equality-a-hard-game-to-win-for-women-footballers-in-argentina/|title=Equality, a Hard Game to Win for Women Footballers in Argentina - Inter Press Service|website=Ipsnews.net|accessdate=4 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2016/07/28/estefania-banini-brings-argentine-skills-to-nwsls-washington-spirit/|title=She struggled to find a soccer team in Argentina. Now she’s a pro in America.|website=Washingtonpost.com|accessdate=4 March 2017}} ==See also== *[[Football in Argentina]] *[[Argentina women's national football team]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Women's football in South America}} [[Category:Women's football in Argentina| ]] {{footy-stub}} {{Argentina-sport-stub}}
